defaultCourses.title: Software Engineering I
defaultCourses.description: Problem analysis and design, team-oriented development, quality assurance, configuration management, project planning.

defaultCourses.title: Intro to Computer Science II
defaultCourses.description: Reinforce and strengthen problem-solving skills using abstract data types and introduce software development practices. Emphasize the use of searching and sorting algorithms and their complexity, recursion, object-oriented programming, and data structures.

defaultCourses.title: Discrete Math for CS I
defaultCourses.description: Logic, sets, functions, matrices, algorithmic concepts, mathematical reasoning, recursion, counting techniques, probability theory. FS.

defaultCourses.title: Program Structure
defaultCourses.description: Program organization paradigms, programming environments, implementation of a module from specifications, the C and C++ programming languages. Pre: 211 or consent.

defaultCourses.title: Basic Concepts of Comp. Science
defaultCourses.description: What is the subject of computer science? What is a computer? Understand the basic models of computation and the concepts of computability, complexity, and network computation, and learn to use them in practice.

defaultCourses.title: Machine Learning Methods
defaultCourses.description: Introduction to contemporary mathematical methods for empirical inference, data modeling, and machine learning.

defaultCourses.title: Discrete Mathematics II
defaultCourses.description: Includes program correctness, recurrence relations and their solutions, relations and their properties, divide and conquer relations, graph theory, trees and their applications, Boolean algebra, introduction to formal languages and automata theory.

defaultCourses.title: Machine-Lvl & Systems Program
defaultCourses.description: Machine organization, machine instructions, addressing modes, assembler language, subroutine linkage, linking to higher-level languages, interface to operating systems, introduction to assemblers, loaders and compilers.

defaultCourses.title: Programming Language Theory
defaultCourses.description: Syntax, semantics, control structures, variable binding and scopes, data and control abstractions. Programming in functional (LISP) and logic (Prolog) programming styles.

defaultCourses.title: Database Systems I
defaultCourses.description: Introduction to relational database systems, data modeling, query processing, transaction processing, storage, and indexing.

defaultCourses.title: Sci, Psych & Phil of Sys Dsgn
defaultCourses.description: Scientific, psychological and philosophical bases of systems design, including a survey of human-factors and ergonomic standards; the nature of innovation and creativity as it relates to systems design.

defaultProfessors.title: Professor
defaultProfessors.course: ICS 314 Software Engineering I, ICS 491: Special Topics.

defaultProfessors.title: Professor
defaultProfessors.course: ICS 312 Machine-Level and Systems Programming, ICS 332 Operating Systems, ICS 332 Operating Systems

defaultProfessors.title: Assistant Professor
defaultProfessors.course: ICS 211 Intro to Computer Science II, ICS 314 Software Engineering I.

defaultProfessors.title: Professor
defaultProfessors.course: ICS 111 Intro to Computer Science I, ICS 685 Virtual and Augmented Reality.

defaultProfessors.title: Associate Professor
defaultProfessors.course: ICS 241 Discrete Mathematics II, CS 483 Computer Vision.

defaultProfessors.title: Professor
defaultProfessors.course: ICS 212: Program Structure, ICS 332: Operating Systems.

defaultProfessors.title: Ph.D. (2020)
defaultProfessors.course: ICS 621: Analysis of Algorithms, ICS 491: Competitive Programming, ICS 443: Parallel Algorithms.

defaultProfessorReviews.review: Easiest Writing Intensive A class you'll take only requires 3 paragraphs for each essay. WOD's are not hard and are really similar to the practice WOD's he gives. Professor basically hands you an A on a silver platter. The professor is a nice guy also and he is willing to help out at any time.

Very all or nothing type of grader. His Workout of the day assignments are relentless and unforgiving(100 points each and he will give you a 0/100 if your code isnt perfect). If you plan on trying to get an A in this class, you must know how to code Javascipt like a seasoned software developer.

Dont get the raving reviews about him, hes just your average researcher 1st professor 2nd. If you can learn from slides great, otherwise he doesn't provide a clear model of the material hes teaching. This is a combination of him speaking rapidly and cramming everything into his lectures.I cant say the homework or examples prepare you for the exam.

Casanova is a very thorough instructor. He provides a lot of information and sometimes it is hard to take it all in, but he's very fair. Just go to office hours for homework help (start assignments early!). Study his slides for quizzes /exams, and you will do fine. Final is a lot like midterm. There is some extra credit opportunity. Do not fall behind!

Cam Moore has a talent for explaining concepts quickly and simply, in ways that are easy to absorb and understand. He also is quite helpful, and you can tell he cares that people actually understand the homework.

There's a quiz every week, plus two midterms and there's not enough time to complete them. Most coding quizzes I don't get the chance to finish, no matter how well I understand the material since we're only given two minutes. He spends class time going over how to do the homework, which I appreciate. Unless you have friends, you work alone in lab.
